--DCL (Data Control Language)
--DCL is used to control access rights and permissions on database objects
--like tables, views, sequences, indexes, procedures, triggers etc.
-->> GRANT and REVOKE

--GRANT -- to give the access of db object to any user
--CREATE a user
create user demo_user identified by admin;

-- To give session access
grant create session to demo_user;

-- To view all system users
select * from all_users where username ='DEMO_USER';

-- GRANT table access
GRANT select, insert, update ON EMP_MASTER TO demo_user;

--Revoke: to take back/remove the access from db object.
revoke delete on emp_master from demo_user;

--COMMENT: to add any descripion or info..
--1. Single line comment: --
--2. Multi line comments: /* */

body:
--SET Operators: are used to combine the results of the select queries.
--1. UNION: removes duplicates and shows unique values from the tables.
select * from emp_main
union
select * from emp_new;

--2. UNION ALL: keeps all values including duplicates.
select * from emp_main
union all
select * from emp_new
union all
select * from emp_new1;

--3. INTERSECT: shows common values that exist in both tables:
select * from emp_new
intersect
select * from emp_main;

--4. MINUS: shows the values from the first query that are not in the second query.
select * from emp_new
minus
select * from emp_main;

--Special operator: REGEXP: it stands for Regular Expressions. It is used
--to search, match, extract or replace text in a smarter way than normal like

--LIKE: simple pattern matching
--REGEXP: advanced pattern matching (numbers, letters, words, formats)

--Types of REGEXP:
--1. REGEXP_LIKE: used to check if a value matches a pattern:
--EG: find names starting with A
select * from emp_new where REGEXP_LIKE(name, '^A');

--eg: find names containing digits
select * from emp_new where regexp_like(name,'[0-9]');

--2. REGEXP_REPLACE: used to remove or replace parts of the text:
--eg: remove all numbers:
select id, regexp_replace(name, '[0-9]','') as name, salary  from emp_new ;

--eg: replace multiple spaces with no space and give space between first and last name:
select id,
regexp_replace(
trim(regexp_replace(name, '\s+', ' ')), -- A mitSharma
'^(\S+)\s+(.*)$',
regexp_replace('\1','\s', '') || '' || '\2'
)as name, salary from emp_new;

--3. REGEXP_SUBSTR: is used to extract the certain part from the column data.

--eg: to fetch the last name of the users:
select id, regexp_substr(name, '\S+$') as name, salary from emp_new;

--eg: to fetch the first name of the users:
select id, regexp_substr(name, [^ ]+) as name, salary from emp_new;

--eg: to fetch only digits inside the name column
select id, salary, regexp_substr(name, '[0-9]+') as name  from emp_new;

body:
-- FOREIGN KEY:
--What is a Foreign Key?
--A foreign key is a column (or set of columns) in one table that links to the primary key/unique key of another table.
--This value must exist in that other table.
--Purpose: To maintain relationships between tables and ensure referential integrity (no orphan records).
--Table1: students:
CREATE TABLE Students (
    stu_id number PRIMARY KEY,  --column level constraint
    name VARCHAR2(100)
);

desc students;

--Table 2 : enrollments:
CREATE TABLE enrollments (
    enroll_id number PRIMARY KEY, --column level
    stu_id number,
    course_name VARCHAR2(100),
    CONSTRAINT fk_stud_course FOREIGN KEY (stu_id)
        REFERENCES Students(stu_id) --table level columns
);
drop table enrollments;
desc enrollments;

--stu_id in Enrollments is a foreign key.
--It points to stu_id in Students.
--This means you cannot insert an enrollment unless that stu_id already exists in the Students table.

INSERT INTO Students VALUES (101, 'A');
INSERT INTO Students VALUES (102, 'B');
INSERT INTO Students VALUES (103, 'C');
INSERT INTO Students VALUES (104, 'D');
select * from students;

INSERT INTO Enrollments VALUES (3, 101, 'Java'); --inserted successfully.
INSERT INTO Enrollments VALUES (2, 105, 'Java'); --integrity constraint voilated

select * from enrollments;
alter table enrollments modify stu_id number unique ;
delete from enrollments where enroll_id=3;

select * from emp;
--Why Disable/Enable Constraints?
--Sometimes you want to:
--Disable constraints ? temporarily stop checks (e.g., while bulk inserting data).
ALTER TABLE Enrollments disable CONSTRAINT FK_STUD_COURSE;
INSERT INTO Enrollments VALUES (7, 107, 'Java');

--Enable constraints ? turn them back on to enforce rules again.
ALTER TABLE Enrollments modify CONSTRAINT FK_STUD_COURSE enable novalidate;

--dropping a constraint
ALTER TABLE emp drop CONSTRAINT CK_EMP_ID_MOBILE_NO;
select * from emp;
--composite primary key
alter table emp add constraint ck_empid_mobile primary key (emp_id, mobile_no);

--Data Loader: It is used to load the data from csv or CTL file
--1. CSV data import: To import the data from CSV file into database table.
--Go to Table -> Import Data -> Select CSV file and perform import.

--2. CTL (Control File Import):
--create .ctl file
--Syntax:

LOAD DATA
INFILE 'students.csv'
APPEND
INTO TABLE students
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
(
stu_id,
name
)
--Above syntax is to add the new data into existing table "students" from the csv file named as "students"

--Syntax2: To add the data given in ctl file itself into database table
LOAD DATA
INFILE *
APPEND
INTO TABLE students
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
(
stu_id,
name
)
BEGINDATA
116, Arjun
117, Riya
118, Shyam

--How to save ctl file:
--1.Click on Save As
--2.Give name of file "students.ctl"
--3.Save file type: All files
--4.Encoding: ANSI

--To open cmd and run the below command from the path where your ctl and csv file is present
sqlldr userid=system/DBS control=students.ctl

--Table: STudents
--Columns stu_id, name
--csv file: students.csv
--ctl file: students.ctl

SELECT * FROM STUDENTS;

--access tables, views, procedures in another database as if they were local.

using '(Description=
(Address=(protocol=TCP)(host=localhost)(port=1521))
(connect_data=(sid=XE)))';
--OR
create database link dbs_link1
connect to system identified by DBS
using 'localhost:1521/XE';


--to access data of source table using db link in DBS2 connection:
select * from emp@dbs_link1 ;
--to delete a database link
drop database link DBS_LINK1;

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
What is UNIX?
It is an Operating System (OS) like Windows or DOS.

Why use Unix ?
 Multiuser OS
 Multi-Tasking
 Time sharing OS
 Network Capability
 Has Pattern Matching Capability
 Has Programming Facility
 Shell Script
 Perl Script
 Secured
 Virus Free

Variants of Unix:
1. AIX (IBM)
2. Linux (Redhat)
3. Linux (Ubuntu)
4. Solaris (Sun Microsystems)
5. HP-UX

Corporate use of UNIX
1. Automation
2. Monitoring
3. To write scripts for job scheduling tools
4. Job scheduling and Control
5. Scripting to handle critical business operations
6. Unix uses less memory to run app services
7. Multiple users can login to one server at a time using virtual machines
8. To store large log files
9. Control Execution of Processes

Difference Between UNIX and LINUX:

UNIX (AIX)
----------------
1. License Based
2. Costly
3. Different flavors of Unix have different cost structures according to vendors

Linux
----------------
1. Open Source
2. Cheaper than AIX and Windows
3. Linux can be freely distributed, downloaded freely, and distributed through magazines or books. There are priced versions also, but they are normally cheaper than Windows.

UNIX Architecture:

User Applications --> Unix Shell --> Unix Kernel --> System Hardware

Unix Shell Types:
1. Bash
2. Bourne
3. Korn
4. C Shell

Unix File Structure:

           / (root)
              |
-----------------------------------
 |    |    |   |   |    |    |   |
 bin  boot mnt etc dev home lib var

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
Unix/Linux Commands:

# pwd : This command will show you  you are in which directory
# cd : cd command use to change directory or go to any particular directory

1) # cal : It will print current month calendar
# cal 1990 It will print 1990 year's calendar
Cal command is having more attributes or multiple options output which you can try.
Go with below command and find the multiple options of cal command.
# man cal

2) # man : man is help command in UNIX. Any commands help/info require then use it.
e.g. : # man date
# man cal
# man find

3) # date : date will print today's date and time.
# date +%m : Month Number will print (1=jan, 2=feb, 3=mar.....)
# date +%b : Month Name will show (Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr......)
# date +%m%h : Month Name and Number both will print
# date +%d : Todays date will print (1, 2, 3, 4,...... 30, 31)
# date +%y : Current year will print (2016, 2017....)
# date +%H%M%S : Hours, Minutes and Seconds
# date +%D : Date will print e.g. 7/24/2016
# date +%T : Time will print e.g. 10:46:32

4) # echo : It will print Message on terminal
# echo Ramesh and Suresh are friends
Above bold message will print on terminal.

5) # echo $HOME : will show which your home directory is.

6) # echo $SHELL : will show which shell you are using (bash, bourne, korn or C)

7) # bc : bc command use for calculator.
Press ctrl + d Key to exit from calculator.

8) # exit : to exit from current session. (ctrl + d) short cut key for exit command.

9) # history : It will record your command history only.

10) # mailx : It use to send chat or mail
Syntax: mailx -s "Subject" shivamshinde159357@gmail.com
--press (shift+enter) to go to next line
Cc:
body
exit (CTRL+D)

subject: LINUX
body:
10) # who : who are the users logged-in into the server.
How many users logged in into the server that will check

11) # whoami : who is the user login into the session.

12) # uname : It will show you which OS you are using (Linux, AIX, SunOS, HP-UX)
# uname -a : shows all details of the system. (OS name, System Configuration, Terminal Detailsetc..)

# uname -s : Shows Kernel details

# uname -n : Shows server name in which you are logged in.

man uname - show you the details of the uname command and all the related options that we can use with it.

13) # hostname : It will also show the server name in which you are logged in.

14) # hostnamectl : It will also show the server name along with its details.

15) # script : script command use to record your session into new file.

e.g. # script history_log.txt
Script started, file is history_log.txt
<Enter some commands>
To stop script, type exit and press [Enter]. Then you will get below massage.
Script done, file is history_log.txt

# cat :- with the help of cat command you can view the containt of history_log.txt file
# cat history_log.txt

16) # mkdir : Use to create directory/folder in UNIX.

 mkdir anushka -- - - - - -- - 1 directory created
 mkdir salman khan -- - -- - - 2 directories created
 mkdir "aamir khan" --------- 1 directory created.

17) # rmdir : Use to delete an empty directories only.

 rmdir anushka

18) # touch : Use to create an empty file in UNIX.

 touch anushka.txt -- - - - - -- - 1 file created
 touch salman khan -- - -- - - 2 files created
 touch "aamir khan" --------- 1 file created

# cat : cat command use to view the file, create the file and Append the file.

# cat >xyz.txt
| this pointer will start and you can type any text here
Later you will (ctrl + d) key to save and exit from cat command.

# cat >>xyz.txt
You can continue with adding new more lines into xyz.txt file.
Press (ctrl +d) save and quiet.

# cat >xyz.txt
If xyz.txt file is already exist then this command will replace new file on it. If not then it will
create new file

1) File types and Permission :
Your fist column shows like for example drwxr-xr-x
If there is d in the start, It means It is a directory. Anything else Apart from d all are files.

Check below screen shot will help you what is type of file

brw-r--r-- 1 unixguy staff 64, 64 Jan 27 05:52 block
crw-r--r-- 1 unixguy staff 64, 255 Jan 26 13:57 character
drwxrwxr-x 2 unixguy staff 48 Jan 26 11:28 directory
prw-r--r-- 1 unixguy staff 0 Jan 26 11:50 fifo
srw-rw-rw- 1 unixguy staff 0 Jan 26 12:00 socket
lrwxrwxrwx 1 unixguy staff 3 Jan 26 11:44 link -> dir
-rw-rw---- 1 unixguy staff 217 Jan 26 14:08 regularfile

Permission will show you like drwxrwxr-x, and first character d means it is directory and after d it is showing like
rwxrwxr-x. Thisis what the permission is having to everyone

r: Read Permission
w: Write Permission
x: Execute Permission
-: No Permission

rwx: All permissions
rw-: Only read and write permission
r--: Only read permission 
---: No permission
-w-: Only write permission
--x: Only execute permission

After doing # ls -l you will get below output
$ ls -l
total 4
drwxr-xr-x 4 root Admin 40 2011-08-17 16:52 Music
drwxr-xr-x 2 root Admin 120 2011-08-17 17:14 Pictures
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root Admin 40 2011-08-17 18:52 abc.txt
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root Admin 40 2011-08-17 18:52 Templates.txt

In above output there are some numbers are showing.

Default link number for file is 1
Default link number for directory is 2

If it 4 showing, It means there are 2 more directories available under Music directory.

2) Owner :
In the 3
rd column owner name will show. A user who created that file or who is having ownership of that
file. In above example root is owner name.

3) Group :
Group Name will show in 4
th Column. root is a user is there under Admin Group.

4) Size :
Size always shows in blocks in UNIX not in kb, mb, gb.

5) Date & Time :
In above mentioned example check your 6th and 7th column, It is your last modified date and time.
Sometime date format shows in below format as well. For example: Jan 26 11:28
Mostly last/previous yearsfiles and folder shows in below format. For example 2011-08-17 18:52

6) File Name :
In the last column It will show you file or directory name

# mv /home/public_html/mylog.txt .

---------------------UNIX Commands Revision----------------------

1) # cal : It will print current month calendar
# cal 1990 It will print 1990 year's calendar
Cal command is having more attributes or multiple options output which you can try.
Go with below command and find the multiple options of cal command.
# man cal

2) # man : man is help command in UNIX. Any commands help/info require then use it.
e.g. : # man date
# man cal
# man find

3) # date : date will print today's date and time.
# date +%m : Month Number will print (1=jan, 2=feb, 3=mar.....)
# date +%j : Month Name willshow (Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr......)
# date +%m%h : Month Name and Number both will print
# date +%d : Todays date will print (1, 2, 3, 4,...... 30, 31)
# date +%y : Current year will print (2016, 2017....)
# date +%H%M%S : Hours, Minutes and Seconds
# date +%D : Date will print e.g. 7/24/2016
# date +%T : Time will print e.g. 10:46:32

4) # echo : It will print Massage on terminal
# echo Ramesh and Suresh are friends
Above bold massage will print on terminal

5) # echo $HOME : will show which your home directory is.
6) # echo $SHELL : will show which shell you are using (bash, bourn, korn or C)
6) # bc : bc command use for calculator.
Press ctrl + d Key to exit from calculator.
7) # exit : to exit from current session. (ctrl + d) short cut key for exit command.
8) # history : It will record your command history only.

Syntax: mailx -s "Subject" abc@gmail.command
Cc:
<Body of email>
Press CTRL+D (to send and exit)

10) # who : who are the users logged-in into the server.
How many users logged in into the server that will check

11) # whoami : who is the user login into the session.

12) # uname : It will show you which OS you are using (Linux, AIX, SunOS, HP-UX)
# uname -a : shows all details of the system. (OS name, System
Configuration, Terminal Detailsetc..)
# uname -e : Shows Kernel details
# uname -n : Shows server name in which you are logged in.

14) # script : script command use to record your session into new file.

# ls - Command: It will show you list of files and directories present in your current folder.

ls -a  : list all files including hidden file starting with '.'
ls --color  : colored list [=always/never/auto]
ls -d  : list directories - with ' */'
ls -F  : add one char of */=>@| to entries
        (* = executable files, / = directory, @ = linking files)
ls -i  : list file's inode index number
ls -l  : list with long format - show permissions
ls -la : list long format including hidden files
ls -lh : list long format with readable file size
ls -ls : list with long format with file size
ls -r  : list in reverse order
ls -R  : list recursively directory tree
ls -s  : list file size
ls -S  : sort by file size

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
(|) Pipe : What is use of Pipe in UNIX?
Output of 1st command gives input to 2nd command.

Examples below.
# ls -l | wc -l

How many lines are there after doing # ls -l that line count will show.

# File and Directory permissions

With the help # chmod command we can change the permissions for files/directories.
1) Relative Permission
2) Absolute Permission
3) Recursive Permission

# Relative Permission
For Relative Permission or Symbolic Method we must be aware of below options.

Reference Class    Description
u    Owner    Files/Directories Owner
g    Group    Users who are members of the files Group
o    Other    Users who are neither files owner nor members of files group
a    All      User + Group Members + All other Members

We will give permission to above reference options. (u=user, g=group, o=other, a=all)

+  Assign Permission
-  Remove Permission

w  Write
x  Execute
r  Read

Syntax:

# chmod ug+rwx abcd.txt
Assign all permissions to user & group for abcd.txt file

# chmod ug-wx abcd.txt
Removed write and execute access from User and group for abcd.txt file.

# chmod a+rwx abcd.txt
All are having all access for abcd.txt file

# Absolute Permission:

The second way to modify permissions with the # chmod command is to use a number to specify each set of permissions for the file.

Always remember below options.

4 = Read
2 = Write
1 = Execute

Number   Octal   Permission Representation
0        ---     No permission
1        --x     Execute permission
2        -w-     Write permission
3        -wx     Execute and write permission
4        r--     Read permission
5        r-x     Read and execute permission
6        rw-     Read and write permission
7        rwx     All permissions

# chmod 777 testfile.txt
Everyone is given all access.
1st 7 is user permission assigned
2nd 7 is group permission assigned
3rd 7 is other users assigned

# chmod 7(user)7(group)7(other) testfile.txt

Some syntaxes below. Review the examples.

# chmod 755 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
-rwxr-xr-x 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# chmod 743 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
-rwxr---wx 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# chmod 043 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
----r---wx 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# Recursive Permission:

# chmod -R 777 suresh
# chmod -R a+rwX suresh

Above is example for recursive permission. We will use -R option for recursive permission.

Above example means the permission will be applied to suresh directory and all files and folders which are under suresh directory.

# chown : to change the owner of the file and directory
# chown <New_owner_id/name> <File_name>
# chown oracle abc.txt

# chgrp : to change the group name
# chgrp <New_group_id/name> <File_name>
# chgrp dba_support abc.txt

mailx configuration:
-----------------------------------------------------------
Install packages (Ubuntu):

sudo apt update
sudo apt install mailutils postfix libsasl2-modules -y


Note:

Choose Internet Site

System mail name  your hostname (press Enter)

2 Enable Gmail App Password


Google Account  Security

 Enable 2-Step Verification

 Create App Password  Mail  Linux

 Copy 16-digit password

# Create SASL auth file
sudo nano /etc/postfix/sasl_passwd

Add:

[smtp.gmail.com]:587 yourgmail@gmail.com:APP_PASSWORD

# Secure & compile
sudo chmod 600 /etc/postfix/sasl_passwd
sudo postmap /etc/postfix/sasl_passwd

# Edit Postfix config
sudo nano /etc/postfix/main.cf

Add at bottom:

relayhost = [smtp.gmail.com]:587

smtp_sasl_auth_enable = yes
smtp_sasl_password_maps = hash:/etc/postfix/sasl_passwd
smtp_sasl_security_options = noanonymous
smtp_sasl_tls_security_options = noanonymous

smtp_tls_CAfile = /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt


Restart Postfix
sudo systemctl restart postfix
sudo systemctl status postfix

echo "Ubuntu mailx Gmail SMTP working" | mailx -v \
-s "Mailx Test" \
-r yourgmail@gmail.com \
recipient@gmail.com

Logs:

tail -f /var/log/mail.log

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
zip & unzip Command
# zip : zip command use to zip multiple files under single output.
  file and folder compression
  compression ratio is less than gzip and bzip2
  can secure zip using password
  
# zip abc.zip 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt 5.txt 6.txt
Output is abc.zip contains all input file i.e. 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt etc

# to zip folder:
zip -r myfolder.zip folder_name

# to zip using password encryption:
zip -e xyz.zip abc.txt

# unzip : unzip command use to unzip the files.
# unzip abc.zip all files will unzipped
# unzip abc.zip 1.txt 1.txt file will unzipped from abc.zip

# gzip : gzip command use to zip the file in UNIX.
Fast compression as compared to zip
compresses one file at a time
creates the file with .gz extension
it will delete the original file.
it is used when speed is important and is commonly used for log files consuming large space

# gzip abc.txt----------------------------------------------- output would be abc.txt.gz
# gzip 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt-----------------output would be 1.txt.gz 2.txt.gz 3.txt.gz etc

To unzip above files use below command
# gunzip : gunzip command use to unzip the files
# gunzip abc.txt.gz
# gunzip 1.txt.gz 2.txt.gz

# bzip2 : zip the file same like gzip command.
compression method with better compression ratio than gzip and zip commands
compresses one file at a time
creates the file with .bz2 extension
it will delete the original file.
When minumum file size is required

# bzip2 abc.txt--------------------------------------------- output would be abc.txt.bz
# bzip2 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt---------------output would be 1.txt.bz 2.txt.bz 3.txt.bz etc

# bunzip2 : unzip the file
bunzip2 1.txt.bz2 2.txt.bz2

Important Note (Very Common Interview Point)
gzip and bzip2 cannot compress folders directly
Use tar with them for directories
Example

tar -czvf backup.tar.gz folder
tar - archive tool
c- create archive
z- compress using gzip
v- verbose (show files)
f- file name of archive

tar -cjvf backup.tar.bz2 folder
tar - archive tool
c- create archive
j- compress using bzip2
v- verbose (show files)
f- file name of archive

# unzip abc.zip all files will unzipped
# unzip abc.zip 1.txt 1.txt file will unzipped from abc.zip

# to view the content of zip file
unzip -l filename.zip

# gzip : gzip command use to zip the file in UNIX.
Fast compression as compared to zip
compresses one file at a time
creates the file with .gz extension
it will delete the original file.
it is used when speed is important and is commonly used for log files consuming large space

# gzip abc.txt----------------------------------------------- output would be abc.txt.gz
# gzip 1.txt 2.txt 4.txt-----------------output would be 1.txt.gz 2.txt.gz 3.txt.gz etc

To unzip above files use below command
# gunzip : gunzip command use to unzip the files
# gunzip abc.txt.gz
# gunzip 1.txt.gz 2.txt.gz

# to view the content of gzip file
gzip -l filename.gz

# bzip2 : zip the file same like gzip command.
compression method with better compression ratio than gzip and zip commands
compresses one file at a time
creates the file with .bz2 extension
it will delete the original file.
When minumum file size is required

# bzip2 abc.txt--------------------------------------------- output would be abc.txt.bz
# bzip2 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt---------------output would be 1.txt.bz 2.txt.bz 3.txt.bz etc

# bunzip2 : unzip the file
bunzip2 1.txt.bz2 2.txt.bz2

# to view the content of bzip2 file
bzip2 -l filename.bz2

# to view the content of tar file
tar -tvf filename.tar

Only 1.txt file will get extracted from abc.tar file.

Use tar with them for directories

Example

c- create archive

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
# tty : shows you terminal name

# stty : shows you terminal details.

# script : script command use to record your session into new file.
e.g. # script history_log.txt
Script started, file is history_log.txt
<Enter some commands>
To stop script, type exit and press [Enter]. Then you will get below massage.
Script done, file is history_log.txt

# cat :- with the help of cat command you can view the containt of history_log.txt file
# cat history_log.txt

### File and Directory Permission:

With the help # chmod command we can change the permissions for files/directories.

1) Relative Permission 2) Absolute Permission 3) Recursive Permission


1). Relative Permission:
For Relative Permission or Symbolic Method we must be aware of below options.

u -  Owner Files/Directories Owner
g -  Group Users who are members of the files Group
o -  Other Users who are neither files owner nor members of files group
a -  All User + Groups Members + All other Members

We will give permission to above reference options. (u=user, g=group, o=other, A=all)

+ : Assign Permission
- : Remove Permission

r -  Read
w -  Write
x -  Execute

Syntax:
# chmod ug+rwx abcd.txt
Assign all permissionsto user & group for abcd.txt file
# chmod ug-wx abcd.txt
Removed write and execute access from User and group for abcd.txt file.
# chmod a+rwx abcd.txt
All are having all access for abcd.txt file.

#Absolute Permission:
The second way to modify permissions with the # chmod command is to
use a number to specify each set of permissions for the file.
Alwaysremember below options.

4 = Read
2 = Write
1 = Execute

0 No permission ---
1 Execute permission --x
2 Write permission -w-
3 Execute and write permission: 1 (execute) + 2 (write) = 3 -wx
4 Read permission r--
5 Read and execute permission: 4 (read) + 1 (execute) = 5 r-x
6 Read and write permission: 4 (read) + 2 (write) = 6 rw-
7 All permissions: 4 (read) + 2 (write) + 1 (execute) = 7 rwx

# chmod 777 testfile.txt
Everyones given all access.
1st 7 is user permission assigned,
2nd 7 is group permission assigned
and 3rd 7 is other users assigned.
# chmod 7(user)7(group)7(other) testfile.txt

Some syntaxes below. Review the examples.
# chmod 755 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
-rwxr-xr-x 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# chmod 743 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
-rwxr---wx 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# chmod 043 testfile.txt
# ls -l testfile.txt
----r---wx 1 amrood users 1024 Nov 2 00:10 testfile.txt

# Recurssive Permission:

# chmod -R 777 suresh
# chmod -R a+rwX suresh

Above example means the permission will applied to suresh directory and the all files
and folders also which are under suresh directory.

# chown : to change the owner of the file and directory
# chown <New_owner_id/name> <File_name>
# chown oracle abc.txt

# chgrp : to change the group name
# chgrp <New_group_id/name> <File_name>
# chgrp dba_support abc.txt

# cp : cp command use to copy-paste files and folders.
Make a copy of a file in a same directory. Use below syntax.
# cp origfile newfile

Few more syntax of cp command below
# cp mylog.txt /home/public_html/backup/
# cp /home/public_html/mylog.txt /home/public_html/backup/
# cp /home/public_html/mylog.txt .
# cp -R : Used to copy directory including all files in it.
# cp -R <directory_name> /root/ram

# mv : mv command use to cut-paste and rename too

Below syntax use for rename in same folder.
# mv old_name.txt new_name.txt

Few syntax below : -
# mv mylog.txt /home/public_html/backup/
# mv mylog.txt /home/public_html/backup/youlog.txt
# mv /home/public_html/mylog.txt /home/public_html/backup/
# mv /home/public_html/mylog.txt .

# Archival using tar
I want to archive multiple files in single output.

# tar : tar command use to create an archive

c- create archive files
v- verbose list files processed
f- use archive file or device
x- extract files from an archive
A- append tar files to an archive

# tar -cvf abc.tar 1.txt 2.txt 3.txt 4.txt 5.txt 6.txt
Output would be abc.tar which is a new file contains all input files.

# tar -xvf abc.tar
All files under abc.tar will get extracted

# tar -xvf abc.tar 1.txt
Only 1.txt file will get extracted

Important Note (Very Common Interview Point)
gzip and bzip2 cannot compress folders directly
Use tar with them for directories

Example

tar -czvf backup.tar.gz folder_name

tar -cjvf backup.tar.bz2 folder

To extract the tar file

tar -xzvf backup.tar.gz
tar -xjvf backup.tar.bz2

sudo useradd user_name

# to delete a user in linux:
sudo userdel user_name

# to give password to user in linux:
sudo passwd user_name

# to view all manually created users:
awk -F: '$3 >= 1000 {print $1}' /etc/passwd

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
####How to copy-paste file from one server to another server?####

With the help of # scp command. We can copy  paste file from one server to another server.

Server 1: abc.google.com /root/ramesh/abc.txt <file available in this server>
Server 2: xyz.google.com
Server3: pqr.google.com

How to transfer abc.txt file to pqr.google.com server. check below syntax.
You are logged in into abc.google.com :- use below syntax

# scp /root/ramesh/abc.txt USERID@pqr.google.com:/root/suresh/

# scp abc.txt userid@pqr.google.com:/root/suresh (If you are in /root/ramesh directory in abc.google.com)

# scp userid@abc.google.com:/root/ramesh/abc.txt . (If you are in pqr.google.com server)
( . dot means it will paste in directory in which you are present and executing the command)

# scp <filename> and enter another server name and path where you need to paste that file.

# head : It will show you 1st 10 lines of the file (default 10 lines)

# head abc.txt (1st 10 lines of the abc.txt files will print)

# head -n50 abc.txt (1st 50 lines of the abc.txt files will print)

# tail : It will show you 1st 10 lines of the file (default 10 lines)

# tail abc.txt (1st 10 lines of the abc.txt files will print)

# tail -n50 abc.txt (1st 50 lines of the abc.txt files will print)

# tail -f : It will show you file which is continuously updating.

# tail -f abc.log

# cut : The cut command in UNIX is a command line utility for cutting sections from each line of files and writing the result to standard output.
It can be used to cut parts of a line by byte position, character and delimiter. It can also be used to cut data from file.

$ cut -c 2 test.txt 2nd characters print
$ cut -c 1-3 test.txt 1 to 3 characters print
$ cut -c 5- test.txt (print from 5th character onwards)

Lets say we have file test.txt with below data:
101:Aman:Linux:70000
102:Ram:Unix:45000

$ cut -d ':' -f 1 test.txt
it will give below output:
101
102

$ cut -d ':' -f 1,2 test.txt
101:Aman
102:Ram

We have added a new line to test.txt and now the data in it is as below:
101:Aman:Linux:70000
102:Ram:Unix:45000
103RamanLinux67000

Now you want to ignore the line which is not having demiliter (:) in it, so the cmd will be:
$ cut -d ':' -f 1,3 -s test.txt
101:Linux
102:Unix

It will ignore third line in output.

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
Process:- Whatever transactions running on Unix Terminal these are the process.

PID: - Process ID
PPID: - Parent Process ID

Child process means it runs under a main process, child process gets the pid and the main process gets the ppid.
Each unix process has two ID numbers assigned to it: Process ID (pid) and Parent process ID
(ppid). Each user process in the system has a parent process.

Most of the commands that you run have the shell as their parent. Check ps -f example where this command listed both process ID and parent process ID.

Process Creation steps:-

Fork :- A process in UNIX created by the fork system which creates a copy of the process that invokes it.

Execute: Fork creates a process but it is not in up status to start the new program. To do that execute comes in the picture.

Wait : The parent then execute the wait system for the child process to get complete.

Process Command:-
# ps : current process status will show.

# ps -f : full listing with PID + PPID
UID        PID  PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD
root         1     0  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:03 /sbin/init
root       742     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:01 /usr/lib/systemd/systemd-journald
ramesh    2145  2130  0 11:10 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
ramesh    2198  2145  0 11:12 pts/0    00:00:00 ps -f

| Column    | Meaning                                                      |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| **UID**   | User ID of the process owner                                 |
| **PID**   | Process ID (unique ID of the process)                        |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID (process that started this process)        |
| **C**     | CPU utilization (recent CPU usage)                           |
| **STIME** | Start time of the process                                    |
| **TTY**   | Terminal associated with the process (`?` means no terminal) |
| **TIME**  | Total CPU time used by the process                           |
| **CMD**   | Command that started the process                             |

# ps -ef : All processes including system + users in full listing.

| Option | Meaning            |
| ------ | -------------------|
| -e | Show **all processes** |
| -f | Full-format listing    |

Output:
----------
UID        PID  PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD
root         1     0  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:03 /sbin/init
root       742     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:01 /usr/lib/systemd/systemd-journald
root      1023     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:00 crond
ramesh    2145  2130  0 11:10 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
ramesh    2198  2145  0 11:12 pts/0    00:00:00 ps -ef

| Column    | Description                                       |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------------- |
| **UID**   | User who owns the process                         |
| **PID**   | Process ID                                        |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID                                 |
| **C**     | CPU usage                                         |
| **STIME** | Process start time                                |
| **TTY**   | Terminal (`?` = no terminal / background service) |
| **TIME**  | CPU time consumed                                 |
| **CMD**   | Command used to start the process                 |

# ps -A : same like # ps -e

# ps -u : Particular users process e.g. # ps -u root

USER       PID %CPU %MEM    VSZ   RSS TTY      STAT START   TIME COMMAND
root         1  0.0  0.1 169084  1248 ?        Ss   Jan08   00:00:03 /sbin/init
root       742  0.0  0.0  51248   840 ?        S    Jan08   00:00:01 systemd-journald
root      1023  0.0  0.0  23120   620 ?        S    Jan08   00:00:00 crond

| Column      | Description                      |
| ----------- | -------------------------------- |
| **USER**    | Owner of the process             |
| **PID**     | Process ID                       |
| **%CPU**    | CPU usage percentage             |
| **%MEM**    | Memory usage percentage          |
| **VSZ**     | Virtual memory size (KB)         |
| **RSS**     | Physical memory used (KB)        |
| **TTY**     | Terminal (`?` = no terminal)     |
| **STAT**    | Process state                    |
| **START**   | Start time/date                  |
| **TIME**    | CPU time used                    |
| **COMMAND** | Command that started the process |

# ps -a : All users details in process.

PID  TTY      TIME CMD
2145 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
2201 pts/0    00:00:00 ps
2250 pts/1    00:00:01 vi

| Column   | Description   |
| -------- | ------------- |
| **PID**  | Process ID    |
| **TTY**  | Terminal name |
| **TIME** | CPU time used |
| **CMD**  | Command name  |

# ps -l : Long list + memory related processes.

F   S   UID     PID   PPID  C PRI  NI ADDR  SZ   WCHAN    TTY   TIME CMD
4   S  1001    2145   2130  0  80   0   -   512  wait   pts/0 00:00 bash
0   R  1001    2201   2145  0  80   0   -   240   -     pts/0 00:00 ps

| Column    | Meaning                                   |
| --------- | ----------------------------------------- |
| **F**     | Process flags                             |
| **S**     | Process state (R, S, Z, T, etc.)          |
| **UID**   | User ID of the process owner              |
| **PID**   | Process ID                                |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID                         |
| **C**     | CPU usage                                 |
| **PRI**   | Priority of the process                   |
| **NI**    | Nice value (priority adjustment)          |
| **ADDR**  | Memory address (usually `-`)              |
| **SZ**    | Size of process in memory (pages)         |
| **WCHAN** | Kernel function where process is sleeping |
| **TTY**   | Terminal                                  |
| **TIME**  | CPU time used                             |
| **CMD**   | Command name                              |

# ps -t : Processes running on terminal.

PID  TTY      TIME CMD
2145 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
2250 pts/0    00:00:00 vi
2301 pts/0    00:00:00 ps

| Column   | Description   |
| -------- | ------------- |
| **PID**  | Process ID    |
| **TTY**  | Terminal name |
| **TIME** | CPU time used |
| **CMD**  | Command name  |

root       742     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:01 /usr/lib/systemd/systemd-journald
ramesh    2145  2130  0 11:10 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
ramesh    2198  2145  0 11:12 pts/0    00:00:00 ps -f

| Column    | Meaning                                                      |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------------------------ |
| **UID**   | User ID of the process owner                                 |
| **PID**   | Process ID (unique ID of the process)                        |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID (process that started this process)        |
| **C**     | CPU utilization (recent CPU usage)                           |
| **STIME** | Start time of the process                                    |
| **TTY**   | Terminal associated with the process (`?` means no terminal) |
| **TIME**  | Total CPU time used by the process                           |
| **CMD**   | Command that started the process                             |

# ps -ef : All processes including system + users in full listing.

| Option | Meaning            |
| ------ | -------------------|
| -e | Show **all processes** |
| -f | Full-format listing    |

Output:
----------
UID        PID  PPID  C STIME TTY          TIME CMD
root         1     0  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:03 /sbin/init
root       742     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:01 /usr/lib/systemd/systemd-journald
root      1023     1  0 Jan08 ?        00:00:00 crond
ramesh    2145  2130  0 11:10 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
ramesh    2198  2145  0 11:12 pts/0    00:00:00 ps -ef

| Column    | Description                                       |
| --------- | ------------------------------------------------- |
| **UID**   | User who owns the process                         |
| **PID**   | Process ID                                        |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID                                 |
| **C**     | CPU usage                                         |
| **STIME** | Process start time                                |
| **TTY**   | Terminal (`?` = no terminal / background service) |
| **TIME**  | CPU time consumed                                 |
| **CMD**   | Command used to start the process                 |

# ps -A : same like # ps -e

# ps -u : Particular users process e.g. # ps -u root

USER       PID %CPU %MEM    VSZ   RSS TTY      STAT START   TIME COMMAND
root         1  0.0  0.1 169084  1248 ?        Ss   Jan08   00:00:03 /sbin/init
root       742  0.0  0.0  51248   840 ?        S    Jan08   00:00:01 systemd-journald
root      1023  0.0  0.0  23120   620 ?        S    Jan08   00:00:00 crond

| Column      | Description                      |
| ----------- | -------------------------------- |
| **USER**    | Owner of the process             |
| **PID**     | Process ID                       |
| **%CPU**    | CPU usage percentage             |
| **%MEM**    | Memory usage percentage          |
| **VSZ**     | Virtual memory size (KB)         |
| **RSS**     | Physical memory used (KB)        |
| **TTY**     | Terminal (`?` = no terminal)     |
| **STAT**    | Process state                    |
| **START**   | Start time/date                  |
| **TIME**    | CPU time used                    |
| **COMMAND** | Command that started the process |

# ps -a : All users details in process.

PID  TTY      TIME CMD
2145 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
2201 pts/0    00:00:00 ps
2250 pts/1    00:00:01 vi

| Column   | Description   |
| -------- | ------------- |
| **PID**  | Process ID    |
| **TTY**  | Terminal name |
| **TIME** | CPU time used |
| **CMD**  | Command name  |

# ps -l : Long list + memory related processes.

F   S   UID     PID   PPID  C PRI  NI ADDR  SZ   WCHAN    TTY   TIME CMD
4   S  1001    2145   2130  0  80   0   -   512  wait   pts/0 00:00 bash
0   R  1001    2201   2145  0  80   0   -   240   -     pts/0 00:00 ps

| Column    | Meaning                                   |
| --------- | ----------------------------------------- |
| **F**     | Process flags                             |
| **S**     | Process state (R, S, Z, T, etc.)          |
| **UID**   | User ID of the process owner              |
| **PID**   | Process ID                                |
| **PPID**  | Parent Process ID                         |
| **C**     | CPU usage                                 |
| **PRI**   | Priority of the process                   |
| **NI**    | Nice value (priority adjustment)          |
| **ADDR**  | Memory address (usually `-`)              |
| **SZ**    | Size of process in memory (pages)         |
| **WCHAN** | Kernel function where process is sleeping |
| **TTY**   | Terminal                                  |
| **TIME**  | CPU time used                             |
| **CMD**   | Command name                              |

# ps -t : Processes running on terminal.

PID  TTY      TIME CMD
2145 pts/0    00:00:00 bash
2250 pts/0    00:00:00 vi
2301 pts/0    00:00:00 ps

| Column   | Description   |
| -------- | ------------- |
| **PID**  | Process ID    |
| **TTY**  | Terminal name |
| **TIME** | CPU time used |
| **CMD**  | Command name  |

Process kill:-

# kill : this command use to kill the process in unix.

# kill <pid of the process>

With the help of # kill if your process is not get killed then you can use below command to kill it.

# kill -15 : e.g. # kill -15 <pid>

# kill -15 101143

# kill -9 : Forcefully killed. E.g. # kill -9 <pid>

# kill -9 101143

Note: # kill -9 is forcefully killed option with the help of this command you can easily killed any stuck or
zombies or daemon processes.

# tee : Output of 1 st command stores in a new file.

# ls lrt | tee abc.txt output of # ls lrt stores in new file i.e. abc.txt

# ps ef | tee abcd.txt output of # ps ef stores in a new file i.e. abcd.txt

With the help of cat command also you can do the same, check below examples
# ls lrt | cat >abc.txt

# sort : sort will sort the file content (lines) alphabetically.

# sort animal.txt

>> to sort the data in reverse order:

# sort -r animal.txt

(|) Pipe : What is use of Pipe in UNIX?

Output of 1st command gives input to 2nd command and for multiple commands execution in single run.

Examples below.

# ls-l | wc -l
25

How many lines are there after doing # ls -l that line count will show.

## Editing terminals in CLI:

Vi Editor/ Nano editor: These are the editors which allows the updating/editing of any files on CLI/terminal itself.

Lets say we have file named as first.txt with below content in it:
Apple
Boll
CAt
Dog
Egg

Now if we need to update the content of this file on terminal itself, we can use vi or nano commands:

### How to edit file using vi command:

vi first.txt

it will open the editor on terminal and you will see the content of file:

Apple
Boll
CAt
Dog
Egg

by default the readonly mode opens in vi editor and to update the content you need to enable the INSERT mode by pressing "i" button.
Now you can edit the content of file

Apple123
Boll
CAt
Dog
Egg
Newline

we have added a new line and made changes in first line, now to save the content and exit from editor press - ESC, which will navigate you to readonly mode, then
press- :wq and enter

w - for saving the content
q - for exiting the editor

### How to edit file using nano command:

nano first.txt

it will open the editor on terminal and you will see the content of file which is directly editable:

Apple
Boll
CAt
Dog
Egg
new line added

To save and exit press: CTRL+O -> ENTER button -> CTRL+X

## Pattern matching command:

> Invert match (not contains)
grep -v "DEBUG" app.log

> using grep cmd with another cmd:
ps -ef | grep java

# nice : Run the job or script as per priority
Nice value          Meaning
-20                 Highest priority
0                   Default priority
+19                 Lowest priority

Lower nice value = higher priority
Higher nice value  = lower priority

syntax:

nice -n -20 tar -cvz backup.tar.gz abc.txt

it will execute the process with highest priority.

body:
crontab/cronjob: is used to schedule the job (commands or scripts) to run automatically at fixed time, date, or intervals.

# to check if cron service is enable or not:

systemctl status cron

# if not enabled/running enable cron using:

sudo systemctl start cron
sudo systemctl enable cron

# to view the current user's cronjobs:

crontab -l

# crontab syntax:

* * * * * 

* - Minute (0-59)
* - Hour (0-23)
* - Day of Month (1-31)
* - Month (1-12))
* - Day of week (0-6) (Sunday =0 and Saturday =6)

SUN-0
MON-1
TUES-2
WED-3
THURS-4
FRIDAY-5
SAT-6

# to view the cron job timing structure you can use crontab guru on google.

# to edit/add any cronjob open crontab in editing mode:

crontab -e

# will execute the job every five minutes

*/5 * * * * /home/shivam/script.sh >> /home/shivam/Documents/script.log 2>&1

To save the changes on crontab:

CTRL + O, ENTER, CTRL + X

Some examples of cron job:


* * * * * echo "Cron is running" >> /home/shivam/cron_test.txt

The above job will run every minute and it will add the text "Cron is running" in cron_test.txt each time it will run.

* * * * * /home/shivam/script.sh >> /home/shivam/script.log 2>&1

Sample content for script.sh file:

#bin/bash

EMAIL="abcd@gmail.com"
HOST=$(hostname)
DATE=$(date)
LOG_FILE="/home/shivam/script.log"

echo "Cron test email for $HOST at $DATE" | mailx -s "Cron run alert on $HOST" "$EMAIL"
echo "Successful run on $HOST at $DATE" >> LOG_FILE

body:
Additional commands used in Application support

1. ssh: it is used to test connectivity of remote server.

# to install ssh service package run:
sudo apt install openssh-server -y

# to check SSH service status:
systemctl status ssh

# ssh into your own VM:
ssh localhost

# installing apache2 service to show the examples of service management:

sudo apt install apache2 -y

-> starting apache service
systemctl start apache2

-> stop service
systemctl stop apache2

-> restart service
systemctl restart apache2

-> check status of service
systemctl status apache2

# to list all the running services in system:

systemctl list-units --type=service --state=running


2. awk: is a text processing command used to search, filter and format data from files.

It is used to monitor logs, reports or for doing RCA.

Syntax:

awk 'pattern {action}' filename

Examples of awk command:

# to print entire file data on terminal:
awk '{print}' app.log

# print specific columns:
awk '{print $1,$2}' app.log

# print line number:
awk '{print NR,$0}' app.log

# filter specific word:
awk '/ERROR/ {print}' app.log

# filter using column value:
awk '$1=="ERROR" {print $0}' app.log

# filter using column value and printing specific columns only:
awk '$1=="ERROR" {print $1, $2, $3}' app.log

## What is find?

The find command is used to search for files and directories in a directory hierarchy.
Its powerful because you can filter by name, type, size, date, permissions, and even run actions on the results.
We cannot find the files/folders name which are archived and present under .tar, .zip, .gz, .bzip2

# Syntax:

find [path] [options] [expression]

# Real-Time Examples:

1. Find a file by name

find /home/user -name "notes.txt"
Searches for notes.txt inside /home/user.

Find all .log files in current directory
find . -name "*.log"
Useful when cleaning up log files.

Find all directories named "backup"
find / -type d -name "backup"
Helps locate backup folders anywhere on the system.

Find files larger than 100 MB
find /var -size +100M
Handy for spotting large files eating up disk space.

Delete all .tmp files
find . -name "*.tmp" -delete
Cleans up temporary files in the current directory.


## What is locate?

The locate command is used to quickly find files by name in Unix/Linux.
Unlike find, it doesnt search the filesystem live. Instead, it looks up a prebuilt database (usually updated with updatedb).
This makes it much faster than find for name-based searches.

# Syntax:
locate [pattern]

# Examples:

Find a file named notes.txt anywhere

locate notes.txt
Instantly shows all paths where notes.txt exists.

Find all .tar files
locate "*.tar"
Useful when you want to quickly list all pictures on your system.

Find configuration files for Apache
locate apache | grep conf
Helps system admins locate config files without manually searching.

Why use locate?
Speed: Much faster than find because it searches a database.
Convenience: Great for quick lookups when you dont remember where a file is.
Limitation: Results may be outdated if the database hasnt been refreshed with updatedb.


## What is awk?

awk is a powerful text-processing command in Unix/Linux.
It works line by line, splitting text into fields (columns) and letting you perform actions like printing, filtering, or calculations.

# Syntax:
awk 'pattern {action}' file

# Examples:

Print the first column of a file
awk '{print $1}' data.txt
If data.txt has multiple columns, this shows only the first one.

Print the second column of /etc/passwd
awk -F: '{print $2}' /etc/passwd
Here -F: sets the delimiter to :. Useful for system files.

Find users with UID > 1000
awk -F: '$3 > 1000 {print $1, $3}' /etc/passwd
Prints username and UID for regular users.

Calculate total of numbers in a column
awk '{sum += $2} END {print sum}' sales.txt
Adds up all values in column 2 of sales.txt.


## Soft Link (Symbolic Link)

A soft link is like a shortcut or pointer to another file.
If the original file is deleted, the soft link becomes broken (it points to nothing).
Can link across different filesystems.

# Example:
ln -s /home/user/report.txt /home/user/report_link.txt

Here, report_link.txt is a soft link pointing to report.txt.
If you open report_link.txt, youll see the contents of report.txt.
If report.txt is deleted, report_link.txt wont work anymore.


## Hard Link:

A hard link is like another name for the same file.
Both the original file and the hard link share the same inode (data on disk).
Even if the original file is deleted, the hard link still works because the data remains until all links are removed.
Cannot link across different filesystems.

# Example:
ln /home/user/report.txt /home/user/report_hard.txt

Here, report_hard.txt is a hard link to report.txt.
Both files are indistinguishable; editing one changes the other.
If you delete report.txt, report_hard.txt still contains the data.

Real-Time Use Cases:
Soft link: /etc/nginx/nginx.conf  linked to /usr/local/nginx/conf/nginx.conf (easy to manage configs).

Hard link: Developers may create hard links for critical log files so even if one is deleted, the data remains accessible.

title: Practice Session
subject: LINUX
body:
## What is find?

The find command is used to search for files and directories in a directory hierarchy.
Its powerful because you can filter by name, type, size, date, permissions, and even run actions on the results.
We cannot find the files/folders name which are archived and present under .tar, .zip, .gz, .bzip2

# Syntax:

find [path] [options] [expression]

# Real-Time Examples:

1. Find a file by name

find /home/user -name "notes.txt"
Searches for notes.txt inside /home/user.

Find all .log files in current directory
find . -name "*.log"
Useful when cleaning up log files.

Find all directories named "backup"
find / -type d -name "backup"
Helps locate backup folders anywhere on the system.

Find files larger than 100 MB
find /var -size +100M
Handy for spotting large files eating up disk space.

Delete all .tmp files
find . -name "*.tmp" -delete
Cleans up temporary files in the current directory.


## What is locate?

The locate command is used to quickly find files by name in Unix/Linux.
Unlike find, it doesnt search the filesystem live. Instead, it looks up a prebuilt database (usually updated with updatedb).
This makes it much faster than find for name-based searches.

# Syntax:
locate [pattern]

# Examples:

Find a file named notes.txt anywhere

locate notes.txt
Instantly shows all paths where notes.txt exists.

Find all .tar files
locate "*.tar"
Useful when you want to quickly list all pictures on your system.

Find configuration files for Apache
locate apache | grep conf
Helps system admins locate config files without manually searching.

Why use locate?
Speed: Much faster than find because it searches a database.
Convenience: Great for quick lookups when you dont remember where a file is.
Limitation: Results may be outdated if the database hasnt been refreshed with updatedb.

If report.txt is deleted, report_link.txt wont work anymore.

------------------- REVISION -------------------

# pwd : This command willshow you  you are in which directory

# cd : cd command use to change directory or go to any particular directory

# cal : It will print current month calendar
# cal 1990 It will print 1990 year's calendar
Cal command is having more attributes or multiple options output which you can try.
Go with below command and find the multiple options of cal command.

# man cal

2) # man : man is help command in UNIX. Any commands help/info require then use it.
e.g. : # man date
# man cal
# man find

# date : date will print today's date and time.
# date +%m : Month Number will print (1=jan, 2=feb, 3=mar.....)
# date +%j : Month Name willshow (Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr......)
# date +%m%h : Month Name and Number both will print
# date +%d : Todays date will print (1, 2, 3, 4,...... 30, 31)
# date +%y : Current year will print (2016, 2017....)
# date +%H%M%S : Hours, Minutes and Seconds
# date +%D : Date will print e.g. 7/24/2016
# date +%T : Time will print e.g. 10:46:32

# echo : It will print Massage on terminal
# echo Ramesh and Suresh are friends
Above bold massage will print on terminal.
# echo $HOME : will show which your home directory is.
# echo $SHELL : will show which shell you are using (bash, bourn, korn or C)

# bc : bc command use for calculator.
Press ctrl + d Key to exit from calculator.

# exit : to exit from current session. (ctrl + d) short cut key for exit command.

# history : It will record your command history only.

# mailx : It use to send chat or mail

mailx -s "Subject"
To:
Cc:
<body>

Press CTRL+D to send the email.

# who : who are the users logged-in into the server.
How many users logged in into the server that will check

# whoami : who is the user login into the session.

# uname : It will show you which OS you are using (Linux, AIX, SunOS, HP-UX)
# uname -a : shows all details of the system. (OS name, System Configuration, Terminal Detailsetc..)
# uname -e : Shows Kernel details
# uname -n : Shows server name in which you are logged in.

# hostname : It will also show the server name in which you are logged in.

# script : script command use to record your session into new file.
e.g. # script history_log.txt
Script started, file is history_log.txt
<Enter some commands>
To stop script, type exit and press [Enter]. Then you will get below massage.
Script done, file is history_log.txt

# cat :- with the help of cat command you can view the containt of history_log.txt file
# cat history_log.txt

# clear : This command use to clear the terminal
